Number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for men 15+ years old

Improve planning and design process; cost of road accidents to the community; optimize movement of people and goods; enhance public transport service; strength law enforcement; contribute to climate change.
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

Output 1: - Centralized / integrated electronic information system developed. - Capacity of GDT enhanced. - Information – specific cadres selected and trained.
Output 2: - Modern blackspot and road safety system established. - Accident investigation procedures enhanced. - Safety conscious - road design system established. - Specialised cadres in blackspot and road safety selected and trained. - Appropriate implementation process of the approved NTTS established nationwide. - Progress achieved toward implementation of the required institutional reform and staff training. - Centres of Excellence and new units established within the GDT. - M & E system established.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: - No centralized / integrated electronic information system available. - Inadequate capacity of the GDT to provide traffic-related services for the stakeholders. - Lack of information expertise.
Output 2: - Absence of modern blackspot and road safety system. - Unavailability of modern accident investigation procedures. - Lack of accident documentations. - Slow progress toward implementation of the required institutional reform to enhance capacity and optimize the use of resources. - Lack of efficient sector-specific skills. - Unavailability of equipment, software, systems, devices and guidelines.

Output1Targets: 1.1 Fully operational system in place and linked with relevant GDT Directorates. 1.2 Protocol to download electronic data and collect data from other sources established. 1.3 User manual and guidelines developed and disseminated to relevant GDT staff. 1.4 Project website established and access provided to decision makers, practitioners and stakeholders. 1.5 Operation police in all Governorates provided with IPAD for data collection. 1.6 Relevant GDT Directorates provided with equipment and socialized software, and institutional management enhanced. 1.7 100 police officers, engineers and technician trained on the use of the system. Output 2 Targets: 2.1 Uniform blackspot and road safety system in use in the 6 Governorates. 2.2 National blackspot guidelines developed and disseminated within the GDT and for relevant Ministries. 2.3 Accident investigation guidelines developed and disseminated within the GDT and General Directorate of Investigation. 2.4 Identification and treatment of 50 blackspots locations per annum. 2.5 Reduction of road traffic fatalities to below 460. 2.6 Reduction of fatality rate per 100,000 populations to below 14. 60 National cadres trained in use of the system Output 3 Targets: 3.1 Efficient system established with support of the Supreme Traffic Council and Deputy Ministers to ensure implementation of the NTTS by relevant Ministries. 3.2 Capacity of the GDT enhanced, and new transport authority approved by the National Assembly in July 2014 and established by the Government in October 2014. 3.3 Organisational structures developed for the new Centres of Excellence and equipment and devises provided on time. 3.4 Guidelines in traffic operations, awareness and driving license developed and disseminated. 3.5 2 International workshops for training of the national cadres in areas which are not available nationally addressed by the Ministers and attended by over 450 people. 3.6 80 women trained in specialized areas. 3.7 Joint pro

Output 1&Output 2 -Project activities in 2016 succeeded initiating and completing the testing phase which is the step preceding the final installation and operationalization of Kuwait Road Accident Data Management System (KRADMS) with Geographical Information System. The testing/pilot phase is continuing and field accident data is being entered into the system as part of the continuation of the testing. In this context, and in order to increase quality and reliability of KRADMs the project has acquired and validated Kuwait Road Data Networks in ArcGIS environment and has acquired and validated high resolution satellite images. Furthermore, project has instituted cooperation with relevant stakeholders such as with Ministry of Electricity and Water (MEW), electricity poles’ numbers have been obtained as ArcGIS Shape file formats for integration into KRADMS (i.e. integration into GIS and Satellite image analysis and Kuwait Road network datasets, which form integral parts). At end of 2016, electricity poles’ data is being verified with the purpose of identifying key road network areas not covered by the data provided. All this serve to set KRADMS on course toward installation and operationalization in 2017.
- While progress was also made in finalizing and launching procurement solicitations of necessary infrastructure requirements that will allow the final installation and full scale operation of KRADMS, the process has faced some delays. The finalization of the procurement and deployment of the necessary requirements is now scheduled for completion in Q1. - While the system is still on testing/piloting phase, around 14 GDT staff received training on the system: around 7 received end user training in Q4 2016 and around 7 police officers received in Q22016 one-day orientation followed by one-day refresher training on use of mobile tablets for data entry in the field. As the system readies for install and operation, around 70 additional staff are expecte

Output 1 1.1 An electronic system to record and manage road accident data in Kuwait (Kuwait Road Accident Data Management System) established and operational with relevant staff of General Department of Traffic(GDT) trained on its application Output 2 21Advanced specialized training programme in field of crash investigation, vehicle dynamics and basic and advanced crash reconstruction courses conducted for 20 cadre of GDT and General Department of Investigation 2.2.Electronic correspondence system within GDT upgraded and expanded to cover 45 locations 2.3.Beta version of Electronic document management system (e Archiving) established, successfully tested and operational at 14 locations of GDT 2.4.Beta version of electronic driver license issuance system launched, comprising one operational kiosk, printer, web portal and mobile application 2.5.Electronic system to electronically manage training activities of Specialized Training Center of GDT established and operational

Output 1 1.1 Kuwait Road Accident Data Management System-KRADMS is completed and moved to live production environment. Approximately 35 members of GDT trained on use of the system-KRADMS Output 2 2.1Current electronic correspondence system updated and upgraded with new advanced functionalities added to advance the e correspondence cycle. 42 offices/desks at GDT equipped and readied with PC and/or correspondence scanners to begin or expand use of the correspondence system 2.2 Specialized training programme in field of advanced crash investigation, vehicle dynamics and basic and advanced courses in crash reconstruction successfully completed. 75% of participants successfully passed/completed all programme courses which began in October 2016 and completed May 2017 2.3 First Version of Electronic Archiving System developed and launched based on requirements collected in earlier phase. Testing of the system is underway to ensure full compatibility with and fulfillment of needs and expectations of GDT. 2.4 Card design, overlay laminates for new smart card driving license approved; Factory Acceptance Testing completed and approved for the smart cards driving licenses and kiosks 2.5 Electronic system to manage trainng activities at GDT has been finalized, launched and readied for implementation; changes and improvements being made to better meet the needs of training center for both training administrators and trainees. Most of the database from old training management system successfully migrated to the new system

PAM plans to improve the labour conditions and management system by analysing the demographic imbalance, making sound decision based on enhanced reporting mechanisms and upgrading its services quality for all economic and social actors.

comment.narrative: Output 2.1: - No research capacity to support evidence-based policy development. - Limited knowledge of non-market drivers of labour mobility. - Labour Mobility Management Structures not fully aligned with GoK’s labour market and economic development goals. Output 2.2: - No available assessment of shelter - No. of workshops held on shelter management - No of study tours held on shelter management - No of technical roundtables on shelter management - No available information on feasibility of AVRR - No migrants assisted with AVRR. Output 3.1: Not enough training to Kuwait Government and social partners, on reporting. Output 3.2: - Insufficient capacity related to international labour standards. Output 3.3: - Not enough training on international Labour Standards. Output 3.4: - No capacity building workshops to parliamentarians held. Output 4.1: 1- No training of a leadership team. 2- No enforcement priorities and no existing plan. Output 4.2: - No existing Labour inspection assessment Output 4.3: - No action plan Output 4.4: - No action plan Output 4.5: - No existing national OSH profile. Output 4.6: - Not enough training of inspectors on OSH. Output 4.7: - No technical capacity of inspectors for monitoring environmental pollutants in the workplace Output 4.8: - weak capacity of employers’ and workers’ representatives on LI and OSH. Output 4.9: - No existing tools. Output 5.1: - No team assembled for the data gathering - No database for gathering and storing data - No data analyzed in graphical form - No data analyzed from month to month Output 5.2: - No database for gathering and storing data - No process for reporting formulated at PAM -No reporting team established Output 5.3: - No training conducted on PAM staff to create, and produce the reports - No training conducted for remaining PAM staff to understand and analyze reports.

Output 2.1: Three comprehensive research reports and three dissemination workshops contribute to evidence –based decisions in PAM, PAM authorities officially recognize value of research and support ongoing research to inform policy development , PAM has greater understanding of how non-market factors impact labour mobility in GoK and recommendations of how to address this, PAM evaluates and implement at least five of the recommendations to better align labour mobility management structure with economic development objectives. Output 2.2: 1Shelter assessment report issued, 5 PAM staff trained on shelter management, 1 Study tour implemented, Output 3: Output 3.1: At least 8 Government, 8 Employers and 8 Workers representatives participated in a Standards training courses in the ILO Training Centre in Turin and Kuwait. Output 3.4: One capacity building workshop held on ILS implementation for parliamentarians
Output 4: Output 4.1 A leadership team of employees of Public Authority of Manpower trained, Needed Enforcement Priorities established and enforcement Plan developed for 24-month period. Output 4.2: Assessment and recommendations completed Output 4.3: Action Plan developed based on Assessment and in support of Enforcement Plan Output 4.4: 75% of Enforcement Plan implemented Output 4.5: OSH Profile and policy produced by PAM. Output 2: A research study (Study #2) to simplify the process related to labour recruitment and employment practices is continuing to take place for the Employment and Recruitment sectors, along with a first draft of business rules and suggested improvements. Work has also started for the Labour Protection Sector.
The research study started in the second quarter of 2016 and continued to take place in 2017 and will come to an end on June 30th, 2017. PAM was supported to enhance its national capacities by establishing a research steering committee, development, and leadership teams to follow up on the developments of the research and take necessary decisions. This adds directly to enhancing the capacity of the national staff and guide them through research approach and methodology. 42 processes were covered and mapped for the employment and recruitment sector along with related business rules.
The project has also started working on the third research study on scenarios related to labour market, and ended on June, 2017. The PAM has implemented concrete steps towards enhancing the efficiency of the government shelter for foreign workers and was supported to develop and automate the databases for the guests in order to enhance data retrieval and reporting function.
The capacities of different departments at the shelter are being developed on managing the different operations of the shelter through IOM’s regional consultants, courses and workshops continuing from the third quarter of 2016.
Output 3:
• Understanding the impact of the labour law for the private sector for 2010 is crucial for future performance of the PAM and to better control the labour market. The PAM was supported to revise the labour law issued in 2010 and study its impact and gaps. A national session is organised in the second quarter to further discuss the law and agree on recommendations and changes on policy level.
Output 4:
The role of the civil society organizations has been also strengt

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to

title.narrative: Institutional Capacity Development for Implementation of the Kuwait National Development Plan

description.narrative: The ICDI/KNDP project seeks to provide a framework of technical support to GSSCPD and CSB and other public entities to create an enabling environment for implementation, monitoring and evaluation and ultimately delivery of KNDP results.
capital of a political entity
Percentage of implementation of the National Development Plan

comment.narrative: New National Development Plan (2015-2018 -- implementation beginning 1 Sept 2015)

-Developed strategic plan for KNDP implementation is endorsed with KPIs integrated. - Review process of GSSCPD Organisational Structure is finalized , including development of functional description for all departments, and comprehensive review for Job descriptions. - Monitoring and Reporting system for GSSCPD to manage consultants is establishment with clearly defined SOPs.

- 70% completed of development process for a Strategic Plan to articulate Kuwait Vision 2035, second and third milestones achieved, including analysis of “Priorities and classified opportunities according to fiscal, economic and social impact and articulate Kuwait 2035 Vision across the identified seven pillars” and Identification of “mid-term objectives and goals across the seven focus areas”. - The new organogram has been endorsed, the administrative divisions with detailed specializations and functional description was endorsed, adjustment of job descriptions to match the new organogram is ongoing. Revision of operational procedures to increase efficiency has started. - A new monitoring and reporting mechanism for GSSCPD linked with the request system for efficient and effective service deliver was completed and approved by the GSSCPD, A satisfaction survey template to measure the satisfaction of beneficiaries against the consultants’ progress and services was developed. Additionally, a guide for public entities (SOP format) was prepared based on consultancy request forms, the roll-out of the system in progress.

- Operational procedures review is completed, adjustment of job descriptions to match the new organogram and be in line with the simplified SOPs is finalised. -Developed strategic plan for KNDP implementation is endorsed with KPIs integrated. - Nation Wide Media Campaign to raise awareness and foster public engagement for KNDP implementation is organised. - Nationally Managed Roster of consultants to foster GSSCPD capacity for provision of advisory services to support KNDP implementation is established. - Needs assessment for the 2020 registered census is conducted, and a system to enhance the data flow to CSB is established and tested.

- A strategic plan to articulate State Vision Kuwait 2035 was finalized, including a comprehensive action plan for implementation by all responsible government entities. - Simplification process for all GSSCPD operational procedures completed, and recommendations provided to improve effectiveness and efficiency of GSSCPD business processes. - National Media Campaign was launched (New Kuwait), the campaign activities targeted wide spectrum of audiences via TV Promos, a dedicated website and social media outlets. - Concert steps were taken for the establishment of (National Roster of Consultants), several profiles were advertised to support KNDP thematic pillars, design of vetting process was completed. - Initial assessment were undertaken to identify needs, a management framework for the 2020 Registered Census was approved.

title.narrative: Kuwait Annual National Energy Outlook (KNEO) project

description.narrative: To provide technical support and capacity building to the Kuwait Institute of Science and Research, for evidence-based sustainable energy policy development by laying the foundation for an annual production of the Kuwait National Energy Outlook report.

document-link.url: https://info.undp.org/docs/pdc/Documents/KWT/Kuwait Annual National Energy Outlook Project Document_Final.pdf

title.narrative: Kuwait Annual National Energy Outlook Project Document

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for women 15+ years old
Number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for men 15+ years old
Total number of new full-time equivalent jobs created
Number of additional implementation support schemes which expand and diversify the productive base, based on the use of sustainable production technologies

Strengthened capacity for Kuwait Institute of Science and Research (KISR) to support evidence-based sustainable energy policy development and planning through annual production of Kuwait National Energy Outlook (KNEO).
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

Output 1 Annual Kuwait National Energy Outlook (KNEO) report initiated Indicators: Annual production of a national energy outlook report.
Output 2 Institutional capacity of KISR for production of KNEO strengthened Indicator: Number of KISR staff benefited from capacity development, exchange visits and training.

comment.narrative:
Output 1 Annual Kuwait National Energy Outlook (KNEO) report initiated Baseline: No existing annual national energy outlook report.
Output 2 Institutional capacity of KISR for production of KNEO strengthened Baseline: Existing capacity development activities at KISR.
N/A
N/A

Output 1 Annual Kuwait National Energy Outlook (KNEO) report initiated Target: Y1: establishment of an editorial committee.
Output 2 Institutional capacity of KISR for production of KNEO strengthened Target: Y1: An assessment of capacity development needs completed.

After several modifications of the objectives and the scope of this project, The Project Document of the Kuwait National Energy Outlook Report (KNEO) was endorsed at the end of second quarter. The main goal of this project is to strengthen the institutional capacity of Kuwait Institute of Scientific Research (KISR) to assist in diversifying Kuwait’s energy resources and achieve its 2030 energy vision of increasing energy supply from renewables to 15% and reduce energy usage per capita through energy efficiency measures. KISR has assigned a full team dedicated to work and look after the implementation of this project, and the process of hiring a Project Coordinator has started but not finalized yet. UNDP Kuwait country office and through the support of the Regional Bureau for Arab States (RBAS), are facilitating a North-South cooperation on energy data processing and documentation with International Energy Agency World Energy Outlook (WEO). In collaboration with KISR a detailed Term of Refence has been developed to facilitate the collaboration with WEO in terms of exchange of ideas, knowledge and experience as well as training KISR’s personnel. Also, through this collaboration a targeted training progeamme will be conducted for forecasting future scenarios annually based on on-going energy research and development activities at KISR. The engagement with WEO will contribute directly to the achievement of the main outcome of this project and its related outputs: OUTPUT 1.1: Annual production of Kuwait National Energy Outlook (KNEO) report initiated. OUTPUT 1.2: Institutional Capacity Development for KISR strengthened.

Output 1 Participation in Multilateral Environmental Agreements (MEAs) and Internationally Agreed Development Goals (IADGs) Strengthened
Targets: - One capacity development measures designed for meeting obligations under signed and ratified MEAs for Kuwait - Three nationally appropriate indicators measured to assess progress on SDGs environment pillars
Output 2 Environmental Information Systems Enhanced
Target: - One existing sectoral environmental databases supported and aligned to KEPA’s eMISK

- Capacity self-assessment (NCSA) to identify capacity building needs relating to MEAs, including national and local needs and cross-thematic issues conducted.
- National capacity building workshops on MEA implementation and readiness for new initiatives to implement the SDG environmental pillars including SDG 13 organized and conducted.
- Assessment of challenges and opportunities for achievement of the SDG environmental pillars in Kuwait, and prepare National SDG Reporting started
- Gap analysis and user survey to assess the state and usage of existing EIS platforms for decision-making processes to implement EPL conducted.

capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1.1 Political Economy analysis or Institutional Context analysis conducted. 1.2 Business model of engagement and staff structure plan developed following the results of the PEA or ICA 1.3 recruited KPPC staff 1.4 Launch event establishing KPPC 2.1 Nudge unit / mechanism established including the experts on behavioural insight recruited 2.2 Number of policy experimentations run by the Nudge unit 2.3 Public Policy Capacity building on evidence-based policy planning 3.1 A communication strategy developed 3.2 Community of Practice developed 3.3 Regional Conference on Policy Planning Challenges and Solutions Pathways (e.g. nudge units) 3.4 Youth and public policy making Initiative 2020

comment.narrative: The results of the strategic planning of the previous five years’ plan (KNDP 2010-2014) indicate that policy targets have not been achieved in most sectors as revealed by the current KNDP 2015-2020. 1. Limited concerted holistic approach 2. Some flaw in the inclusive and review approach of the policy-making process. Lack of holistic approach underlies lack of impact assessment or feedback mechanism 3. Some inconsistencies in the methodological policy and policy planning approach where policy making is not established on the best available evidence from a wide range of sources and stakeholders and often lacks implementation relevance.

The General Secretariat of the Supreme Council for Planning and Development aims to address this levelling up the policy making performances gearing up and preparing for the KNDP 2020. Skill diagram report, Executive, SOPs, Risk Management plans documents. Recruited staff Press release for the launch of the KPPC TORs and recruitment papers Digital products manuals, training session’s manuals, visits participants’ feedback, plan documents Strategy progress report, final communication strategy document.

1- Governance document and framework developed for the KPPC; 2- Functional job descriptions developed; 3- Business flow model and SOPs 4- Policy advisors for the 5 KNDP pillars recruited 5- Health policy white paper with KFAS and LSE 6- Nudge Unit established and COP for Nudge 7- Monthly lecture series conducted at KPPC 8- Political Economy Analysis (PEA) and Institutional Context Analysis (ICA) 9- Macroeconomic Model for Kuwait

title.narrative: Demonstration project for HCFC-free lof-GWP technology performance in air-conditioning applications

description.narrative: Project involve install of air-con equip in selected locations in residential areas in Kwt with HCFC free low-GWP tech over 2 seasons of summer & dissemination of test results to other interested stakeholders – both national & int'l.

Project involve install of air-con equip in selected locations in residential areas in Kwt with HCFC free low-GWP tech over 2 seasons of summer & dissemination of test results to other interested stakeholders – both national & int'l.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

- Information on performance of an environmentally safe and cost-effective alternative for is available enabling replication of the technology in Kuwait in air-conditioning applications for the indicated capacity. - Availability of product performance results of HFC-32 and R-290 based technologies which are currently available in the market.

comment.narrative: - No information on performance of an environmentally safe and cost-effective alternative for enabling replication of the technology in Kuwait in air-conditioning applications for the indicated capacity. - No product performance results of HFC-32 and R-290 based technologies which are currently available in the market.

To install commercially available of air-conditioning equipment in selected locations in residential areas in Kuwait with HCFC free low-GWP technologies (e.g., HFC-32, R-290), test performance of these equipment in prevailing conditions in Kuwait over two seasons of summer and disseminate test results to other interested stakeholders – both national and international.

The project implementation structure was designed with dependence on expertise of Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research and with inputs from National Ozone Unit and UNDP. The Project implementation is not according to the approved plan, due to a delay in the technical inputs to be provided by KISR relating to the type of equipment to be tested and performance assessment process for the different equipment proposed. The procurement of the monitoring equipment is expected to take place on the first quarter of 2018, in order to start the monitoring and testing for two selected locations using HFC-32 and R-290 based technologies.
